Recently, we've been revisiting some of this year's most interesting stories.
One of them took place in Jena, Louisiana, a small town of 3,000 people.
It was a long and complicated story about race in America and NPR's Wade Goodwyn has been covering it for us.
Wade, remind us what happened in Jena and where the story began.
Well, with the Jena story, even that is tricky.
When the story began as a matter of some dispute and it depends on whether you're black or white.
If you're black, it started when a black high school freshman asking a school assembly if he could sit under this big tree in the courtyard where the white students traditionally sat.
And he was told he could sit in where he pleases, but the next morning when the kids got to school, there were nooses hanging in that tree.
The school board decided the incident was a prank and they let the white boys get in-school suspension.
And that punishment did not sit well with the black students.
Their parents were the larger black community in Jena, which is about 10 percent, I think.
Now, most of the whites in Jena believed the noose hanging was a completely separate event from the attack by six black students on a white student named Justin Barker, which happened months later.
And then that was the match that led the protest fires - when those six black students were charged with attempted murder.
Instead of simple assault, they became the Jena Six.
Mychal Bell, who is one of the Jena Six, was the first defendant to go on trial and he was convicted by an all-white jury.
But then, that conviction was thrown out.
What's the latest with him?
Mychal Bell's first trial ended up being something of a fiasco.
Bell's court-appointed attorney seemed not up to the task of mounting a vigorous defense.
He tried to negotiate a plea deal.
But instead of negotiating with his client, he negotiated with his client's grandmother.

And when Mychal Bell was informed of this deal outside the courtroom, he said no. And in response, Bell's defense lawyer refused to put on any defense at all and simply rested immediately after the prosecution presented their case.
The subsequent guilty verdict was thrown out by an appeals court, not because of any issue with Bell's defense attorney, but because Bell was a juvenile at the time of the assault.
And the court said he never should have been tried as an adult in the first place.
Now, by this time, Mychal Bell and the Jena Six had become famous.
And I don't think the judge, the DA, or Bell's new defense lawyers wanted any long drawn-out spectacle where the town of Jena would have ended up being on trial as much as Mychal Bell.
So they had a plea arrangement.
He was pleaded guilty to battery.
And I've been told by his lawyers he's been moved to a halfway house and he could spend most of the next year incarcerated there.
Earlier this week, The Congressional Black Caucus called on the governor of Louisiana to pardon Mychal Bell and the other five members of the so-called Jena Six.
And they argued that they and their families have suffered enough at this point.
The Congressional Caucus has asked the governor to pardon them, but there has to be some recommendation to the governor by a board - none of these things have happened yet.
You know, five of these boys have not even been convicted yet.
Wade, tens of thousands of African-Americans traveled to Jena to protest.
Now, the story has passed a bit.
What's it like in Jena now for the families of the defendants?
I think after the protest, Jena went back to normal.
And I am not inclined to believe that normal means an environment that's actively hostile to black people.
I mean, the fact is in small towns across the south - and I would argue outside the south, too - law enforcement is sometimes used as an instrument of oppression.
And that's not just in small towns either.
When these situations do blow up, the white community often feels mischaracterized and traumatized.
So there is some bitterness that ensues.
But that's usually directed at the media, not really at the local black population who, by and large, the whites have known all their lives.
So when the white community protests that they have always treated the black community with Christian intentions, they mean it and they believe it.
And I would suspect many are trying to prove it now, more than ever.
So the black community in Jena, including most of the families of the Jena Six, are still there doing the best they can.
NPR's Wade Goodwyn, thank you so much for revisiting the story with us.
It was my pleasure.

Afghanistan's economy?

special adviser to Afghanistan.

Joining us today from our NPR headquarters in Washington, D.C., is economist Julianne Malveaux, the president and CEO of Last Word Productions.

From our New York bureau, Walter Field, CEO and publisher of the NorthStarNetwork.com; and Glenn Loury, professor of the social sciences and professor of economics at Brown University is at member station WRNI in Providence, Rhode Island.
Welcome everybody, and Glenn, let me start with you.
Latinos are a huge population in the United States, but not everyone is a citizen, and not all citizens vote.
Not all citizens of any race vote.
How much are Latinos, do you think, going to be able to impact the elections of 2006?
Well, I don't know.

I'm not an expert on the politics side, but there can be no doubt that the presence of Latinos in American society is going to be exerting a profound impact on us for many generations to come across a broad front.

I think the immigration issue a potential time bomb for the Republicans in that, while the president has shown some leadership in proposing, you know, some efforts to regularize the situation of people in the country, others in the Republican Party have seen it in their interest to demagogue this issue a little bit because there's a lot of resentment of immigration abroad in the country.
And that could really redound to the detriment of the Republicans in the long run if they alienate the Latino voter.
Finally, I would say that I think African-Americans have a particular interest in how Latinos assimilate themselves into the American political structure.
It matters a lot as to whether or not Latinos are sympathetic to African-American claims.

I think opportunity may be being missed for black politics in not taking the Martin Luther King legacy and applying it in a progressive way to the situation of, especially, undocumented workers in the country, because that might garnish sympathy from Latinos, which would be politically beneficial to blacks in the long run.

Julianne, I remember reading a book called Black and Multi-racial Politics that examines cities where, basically, black and brown people, if you want to put it that way, were a majority in the city when put together but never really acted jointly for political goals.
Do you feel like blacks and Latinos are going to begin to interact more profoundly, more deeply and more aggressively, or is it just going to be oil and water?
Well, I think that it's a mutual interest, as Glenn has said, for people to act in concert.
I think that, however, white folks have had a lot of fun playing these two groups off against each other.
I remember in 2000 when the census numbers were coming, and I was watching This Week.

George Will sat on that panel and virtually salivated and said: African-Americans are no longer going to be the largest majority, and if we can get Latinos to vote with us - I mean, he just went there.
And you've seen a fair amount of that.

You've also seen African-American gains have been tenuous, Farai, that all too often when you see a Latino aspiring politician -we saw it with Villaraigosa in L.A., we've seen it in New York - the tension is palpably there.
But when we look at a series of economic issues, especially when we look at wage issues, what you often will see is that there are points of synergy.
When you look at a leader like a Dennis Rivera in New York, who leads low-wage workers, and you talk about the cross-over there, those are the things that we have to bear in mind.
Here's the difference, though.
Latinos have tended almost to split their vote with Republicans, while African-Americans have not.
And I remember former Congressman Bill Clay saying, you don't have permanent friends or permanent enemies but instead, permanent interests.
When are our interests are the interests of economic justice - social and economic justice - there will be times when we can and must align with our Latino brothers and sisters.
But there may be also times we do not.
Latino population is not unified on the immigration issue, either.
Talk to some second and third generation Latinos about what they think about immigration, and they too, for interesting reasons, have some ambivalence.

Walter you know, on that point, I remember going to a rally that we covered here on NEWS & NOTES and there were a few black and Latino supporters of the Minutemen, who were an anti, or not an anti, but a border enforcement militia I guess you'd call it.
So certainly not all Latinos are the same and not all African-Americans are the same.
It may be foolish expect that.
Yeah.
Absolutely.
But in the long run what do you think politicians are going to start doing to really recruit Latinos?
And will that act to the detriment of African-American interests or will it be one big happy political family?
Well, we have practical experience here in New York City.
We're on vote away from having a majority black and Latino New York City Council.
The last mayoral election, the majority of voters in New York City were black and Latino.
We have experience with non-citizen voting.
For almost 30 years in New York City, non-citizens could vote in local school board elections.
There is now a bill before the New York City Council that will bring that back but for municipal elections.

So I think when we start talking about engaging Latino voters I think we have to talk about the broader issue of civic engagement, because there are a number of ways that you can be civically engaged beyond voting.
In New York City, I'm hoping to see a day when we bring back non-citizen voting, particularly in local municipal elections.
Because if you get people engaged at a local level, it becomes more likely that they will vote for their state legislature, for members of Congress and in a presidential election.
